citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The alpaca’s nails on all four limbs were excessively overgrown and curling laterally and underneath causing an abnormal
separation of the toes. The excessive nail lengths cause the animal to stand and walk abnormally. Abnormal posture and
gait may cause strain on joints and may be accompanied by possible pain and/or discomfort and joint damage.
Additionally, the two potbelly pigs’ hooves were overgrown and in need of trimming at the time of inspection. Failure to
trim hooves in a timely manner may cause pain and/or an abnormal gait which may lead to joint damage or discomfort.
The licensee stated that he had observed the overgrown nails and hooves but had not had someone out to trim them yet.
Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of
appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries.
To be corrected by 6/28/2024.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A domestic quail chick that, according to the licensee, hatched approximately two days ago on Sunday, June 23, 2024,
was observed to be unable to walk with its legs splayed to opposite sides of its body. It was observed to be repeatedly
stepped on and run over by the ~6 larger conspecifics, of varying ages, as they rapidly moved around the enclosure. In
addition, the chick was observed flinching abruptly when stepped on by the other birds. Furthermore, the chick was not
observed eating or drinking at the time of inspection.
The licensee failed to identify that the chick was failing to thrive, possibly injured, and potentially unable to access food or
water while being stepped on by the other birds in the enclosure. The licensee is required to perform daily observation of
all animals to assess their health and well-being. A mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that
timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending
veterinarian.
To be corrected today, 6/25/2024.
Multiple different species were observed exhibiting health and welfare conditions that the licensee failed to identify.
• A juvenile guinea pig in the female guinea pig enclosure had ~1.5 cm area of red, inflamed, and scabbed skin with hair
loss above the left eye. This may lead to pain and infection if left untreated.
• One of the female Fennec Foxes had ~3 cm area of hair loss on the right flank. The skin appeared intact and not
inflamed. If not evaluated, this condition may worsen and cause pain or distress to the animal.
Daily observation of all animals is required to assess their health and well-being. A mechanism of direct and frequent
communication is required so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being
is conveyed to the attending veterinarian.
To be corrected by 7/9/2024.
A complete routine inspection was conducted starting on 25 June 2024. This inspection report is limited to the Direct non-
compliances identified during that inspection. An additional inspection report will be delivered with the other issues
identified during this inspection.
This inspection was conducted with the licensee. The exit briefing was conducted on 25 June 2024 with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Leann Sargeant, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The alpaca’s nails on all four limbs were excessively overgrown and curling laterally and underneath causing an abnormal 
separation of the toes. The excessive nail lengths cause the animal to stand and walk abnormally. Abnormal posture and 
gait may cause strain on joints and may be accompanied by possible pain and/or discomfort and joint damage.  
 
Additionally, the two potbelly pigs’ hooves were overgrown and in need of trimming at the time of inspection. Failure to 
trim hooves in a timely manner may cause pain and/or an abnormal gait which may lead to joint damage or discomfort. 
 
The licensee stated that he had observed the overgrown nails and hooves but had not had someone out to trim them yet. 
Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of 
appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries.  
 
To be corrected by 6/28/2024. 
2.40(b)(3)  Direct

all animals to assess their health and well-being. A mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that

To be corrected today, 6/25/2024.

Multiple different species were observed exhibiting health and welfare conditions that the licensee failed to identify. 
• A juvenile guinea pig in the female guinea pig enclosure had ~1.5 cm area of red, inflamed, and scabbed skin with hair

To be corrected by 7/9/2024. 
 
A complete routine inspection was conducted starting on 25 June 2024. This inspection report is limited to the Direct non-

Leann Sargeant, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
